name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: ✅ Kimberly Vaughan Firearm Safe Storage Act: Require the U.S. Attorney General to establish best practices for the safe storage of firearms. (10/11)

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text:
✅ Closing the Bump Stock Loophole Act: Define bump stocks and ban the manufacture, sale, or possession of bump stocks for civilian use.

Bump stocks allow an assault-style weapon to shoot more than one shot with a single pull of the trigger. (9/11)

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: ✅ Safe Guns, Safe Kids Act: I also cosponsored this bill to impose a penalty of up to five years in prison on those who violate safe storage by allowing a minor to obtain a firearm which the minor then uses to cause injury or death. (8/11)

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: ✅ Ethan’s Law: I was proud to cosponsor this bill to set federal standards for safe gun storage in homes & give states incentives to implement their own laws — named for 15-year-old Ethan Song, who accidentally killed himself with an unsecured firearm in a friend’s home. (7/11)

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text:
✅ Untraceable Firearms Act: Subject ghost guns, untraceable guns without serial numbers that can be bought and assembled at home without passing a background check, to existing federal firearm laws.

We also included firearms assembled using 3-D printing. (6/11)

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: ✅ Keep Americans Safe Act: Ban the import, sale, manufacture, transfer, or possession of large-capacity magazines. (5/11)

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: ✅ Prevent Gun Trafficking Act: Create new federal offenses for “straw purchases,” an illegal purchase where someone agrees to buy a gun for someone else who is ineligible to own a firearm, to combat illegal gun purchases and transfers. (4/11)

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: ✅ Raise the Age Act: Raise the minimum lawful federal age to purchase assault-style weapons from 18 to 21 years old. (3/11)

For 30 years, the 340B Drug Pricing Program has allowed clinics and hospitals to provide lower-cost prescription drugs to millions of patients.

And how much does it cost taxpayers?

$0.

We must #Defend340 so that these healthcare providers can continue to serve our communities.

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text:
16 big pharma companies are breaking the law and refusing to comply with federal 340B prescription drug discounts for healthcare providers and patients.

Tonight, I’m leading a group of my colleagues on the House floor in calling on @HHSGov to enforce the law NOW and #Defend340B.

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: RT @CulpeperSE: During a bipartisan Special Order Hour in the House chamber Tuesday, lawmakers will try to protect patients, rural health-c…

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text:
Gilead is one of 16 big pharma companies breaking the law and refusing to comply with 340B.

They are forcing clinics to pay more money for lifesaving drugs — drugs that are distributed at little to no cost to people living with HIV/AIDS who need them to survive.

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text:
Tonight, I’ll be speaking on the House floor to #Defend340B.

Congress created the 340B program in 1992 to protect healthcare providers and patients from rising drug prices.

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text:
Big pharma company @GileadSciences might publicly update their profile with a rainbow logo and prominently feature the word “PRIDE” to reflect the month.

But behind the scenes, they are targeting HIV/AIDS clinics and threatening to shut them down to raise their own bottom line.

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger

The House intends to take up legislation on these orders, and I hope my colleagues will consider how these measures can save the lives of those in crisis and those around them. (4/5)

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text:
When similar provisions were in place from 1994 to 2004, mass shootings declined by 37%.

Once they expired, gun massacres increased by 183%, killing Americans of all ages at school, church, the grocery store, concerts, night clubs — anywhere people gather in community. (3/5)

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: This bill, the Assault Weapons Ban, defines the types of weapons that are manufactured for the quick killing of people and the legislation explicitly exempts more than 2,200 guns that are used for hunting, home defense, or recreation. The bill also limits magazine capacity. (2/5)

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text:
Without concrete action, the cycle of mass carnage in this country will go unbroken.

We need to move towards reinstating a ban on the manufacturing, sale, and transfer of military-style assault weapons currently on the market.

Let me introduce you to H.R. 1808. (1/5)

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text:
Outrageously, these efforts have stalled in the U.S. Senate.

These efforts are broadly popular across the political spectrum. The Senate could enact these laws right now if Senate Republicans wanted to show concern for the desperate outcries from America’s communities. (5/5)

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: Closing this loophole would not only help protect our communities, but it would also protect the federal agents who are responsible for reclaiming the weapons sold to people who should have failed a background check via this loophole before their check could be completed. (4/5)

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: This second piece of legislation would close the “Charleston Loophole” which allowed the Mother Emanuel Church murderer to purchase a firearm despite being prohibited by law. (3/5)

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: The House has also voted twice in support of the Enhanced Background Checks Act to extend the period that law enforcement has to complete background checks for the small percentage of individuals who are not cleared within minutes of submitting a background check. (2/5)

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text:
Endemic mass shootings are unique to the United States.

The problem is about access to assault weapons.

It is time to get serious about protecting America’s children — and all Americans — from gun violence.

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text:
The sad reality is that requiring would-be mass murderers to reload saves lives — permitting people escape time and law enforcement response time.

This is why I support legislation to limit magazine capacity. (3/3)

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text:
That provision was part of the 1994 Federal Assault Weapons Ban, which expired in 2004.

Large capacity magazines equate to more fatalities when a would-be shooter can fire shot after shot.

Research confirms that limiting magazine capacity saves lives. (2/3)

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text:
When I began as a federal agent, I carried a gun and two extra magazines every day.

My mags were marked “for law enforcement use only” because they held more than 10 rounds. At that time, federal law limited magazine capacity to 10 rounds outside of law enforcement use. (1/3)

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text:
The federal purchasing age for handguns is 21.

The federal purchasing age for assault rifles is 18.

Both the Uvalde and Buffalo shooters bought their assault weapons at 18.

Raising this age is a first step to protecting lives and establishing parity in federal firearms law.

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: We must pass commonsense, data-driven legislation to save lives — background checks, Extreme Risk Protection Orders, and magazine capacity limits.

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text:
In the months ahead, our system will be tested. 

Its strength will depend on our ability to defend the truth, and its survival will depend on our commitment to combatting extremism and rejecting calls for political violence. 8/9

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text:
This day did not happen in a vacuum.

January 6 marked the continuation of a trend of falsehoods — and tragically, the lies that spawned this act of insurrection are still present in American politics. 7/9

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: The events of that day are a warning about what can happen to the threads of our democracy when American lawmakers — including former President Donald Trump — choose to traffic in dangerous conspiracy theories. 6/9

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text:
We cannot and should not “move on” from the events of January 6, as has been suggested in recent days by several of my colleagues.

These colleagues fail to recognize the severity of what occurred on that day and what has occurred in the year since. 5/9

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text:
Had it not been for the bravery of the U.S. Capitol Police and Metropolitan Police — including the more than 140 officers who were injured on that day, we very likely might have lost our lives in the House gallery.

Their sacrifices prevented evil from winning the day. 4/9

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: In those moments, there is no question that we witnessed firsthand a violent attempt to undermine a free and fair election — not on foreign shores, but in the U.S. Capitol Building. 3/9

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text:
We watched as U.S. Capitol Police officers bravely fended off a violent attack.

We furiously texted loved ones, we helped colleagues process this moment of crisis, we heard the cries of “hang Mike Pence” outside the doors, and we prepared to deploy gasmasks. 2/9

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text:
I was barricaded in the House Chamber on January 6.

I was physically there as insurrectionists — domestic terrorists — clawed at the doors of the U.S. House of Representatives.

Those of us stranded in the gallery were among the final Members of Congress to be evacuated. 1/9

tweet_text: A government shutdown would hurt millions of hardworking Americans during the holidays, cost taxpayers billions of dollars, and leave our national security more vulnerable — all while we contend with yet another highly contagious strain of COVID-19. https://t.co/Udcl0x7jBz

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: The #AmericanRescuePlan provides a historic increase in the Child Tax Credit — so that Virginia families will receive an extra boost as we accelerate the fight against this virus.

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text:
A family of four making $90,000 per year with a child over 6 and a newly eligible child age 17 or older:

Will receive $9,100 — $5,600 in stimulus, a boost in the CTC of $1,000 plus $3,000 for the older child, minus the $500 credit for a dependent not receiving the CTC.

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text:
A family of four making $105,000 per year with one child under 6 and one child age 6 or older:

Will receive $8,200 — direct stimulus payments of $5,600 and a boost in the CTC of $1,600 and $1,000, respectively.

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text:
A married couple making $40,000 per year with one child age 6 or older:

Will receive $5,200 — $4,200 in direct stimulus payments plus a $1,000 boost in the CTC.

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text:
A married couple making $40,000 per year with one child under the age of 6:

Will receive $5,800 — $4,200 in direct payments, plus a boost in the CTC of $1,600.

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text:
The #AmericanRescuePlan includes a major expansion of the Child Tax Credit for Virginia parents — with payments beginning to arrive in July.

Examples 👇

A 40-year-old couple with two kids making $103,000 per year:

Previously paid $1,594 per month in premiums — or 18.5 percent of their income.

Now they pay $731 — saving more than $10,000 per year.

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text:
A 50-year-old couple with a 25-year-old adult child making $85,533 per year:

Previously paid $1,793 per month in premiums — or 25.15 percent of their income.

Now they pay $606 per month — a savings of more than $14,000 per year.

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text:
A 60-year-old married couple making $67,800:

Previously paid $2,118 per month in health insurance premiums — or 37.48 percent of their income.

With the American Rescue Plan they pay $480 per month — saving nearly $20,000 per year.

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text:
11 years ago today, the #ACA became law.

Now, the #AmericanRescuePlan lowers healthcare costs by capping insurance premiums at eight and a half percent of income for EVERY income level — saving many Virginia families thousands per year. #ProtectOurCare

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: Community healthcare providers in #VA07 alerted me to the issue, and I started working to rally bipartisan support for protecting #340B. Today, 216 Members of Congress – from both parties – signed on to my letter demanding that HHS protect the prescription drug discounts.

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: Big pharmaceutical companies have teamed up with the company Kalderos to try to change the rules of the #340B program – without the approval of Congress, or HHS. Their changes would drive up prescription drug prices for the types of healthcare providers I mentioned above. #VA07

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: The types of providers that depend on #340B discounts include Federally Qualified Health Centers, rural hospitals, Ryan White HIV/AIDS clinics, and safety-net clinics serving low-income Virginians. These places serve some of the most vulnerable people in #VA07.

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: The #340B program was created by law. In exchange for getting their drugs covered by Medicaid healthcare plans, the program requires drug companies to give discounts to healthcare providers that serve at-risk Americans. #VA07

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: Today, I demanded that Secretary Azar take immediate action to protect the #340B Drug Pricing Program. Pharmaceutical companies are currently trying to make changes to the program that would spike up drug costs for community clinics and hospitals in #VA07. Thread 👇

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text:
The #340B program provides discounts on prescription drugs to clinics & hospitals that serve the most at-risk Americans. Drug companies are now trying to rewrite the rules, and take away these essential discounts.

I'm working to stop them. Details ⬇️
https://t.co/ChO11urC7B

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: This is only one of the ways that the Lower Drug Costs Now Act would fight rising drug prices. The bill also gives Medicare Part D the power to negotiate directly with drug companies, and those lower prices would also be available to Americans with private insurance. (5/5)

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: The AIM price is a volume-weighted average of the price of prescription drugs in Australia, Canada, France, Germany, Japan, & the United Kingdom. If there's no AIM price for a certain drug, the max in the United States would be capped at 85% of the avg. manufacturer price. (4/5)

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: For drug price negotiations between PBMs and big pharmaceutical companies in the United States, the Lower Drug Costs Now Act would set the max price at 120% of the average international market, or AIM price. (3/5)

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text:
Why does it matter what someone pays for a prescription drug in another country?

The Lower Drug Costs Now Act, which I cosponsored and voted to pass, would set max prices for U.S. drugs based on average prices in comparable countries. (2/5)

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: U.S. drug prices are nearly 4 times higher than the average prices in similar nations like Australia & Germany. Even accounting for rebates, Americans pay more than their counterparts overseas – you can visit https://t.co/WmLMolbx8F to see comparisons for your medication. (1/5)

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: Amid the partisan rhetoric, we can't lose sight of what the #ACA actually means to Americans. If the administration succeeds in repealing it, Medicaid expansion is no longer law, & tens of thousands of Central Virginians would lose their affordable, quality health coverage. #VA07

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: Under the #ACA, states were allowed to expand the number of Americans eligible for Medicaid. In #VA07 alone, that meant about 50,000 people finally got health insurance. About 3,000 of them were finally able to get help with an addiction, and hundreds were treated for cancer.

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text:
Lack of internet has a very real impact on #VA07 families and their access to education, telehealth, and economic opportunity. COVID-19 has only made the issue more urgent.

Just yesterday, I sent a new broadband survey to my constituents – I've already received 800+ responses. https://t.co/uwrkrwpuj3

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: “In Powhatan County, about 33 miles west of Richmond, 1 in 4 rural residents lack a sound connection. Schools Superintendent Eric Jones said some parents decided to home-school their children this year since they could not participate virtually." #VA07 https://t.co/qcxK1GbWOZ

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: The deadline to compete in the Congressional App Challenge is only a few days away! #VA07 students should submit by Monday, October 19. More details on the annual #STEM competition: https://t.co/pW6Zbfnd1O

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text:
The first Virginia Black Business Expo will be held this Saturday afternoon at the Fredericksburg Fairgrounds. I hope many of you will be able to turn out for a great event supporting Central Virginia entrepreneurs & small business owners. #VA07
https://t.co/Td5B08FiBi

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: To meet today's cybersecurity challenges, we need to understand that in China and elsewhere, there are closely intertwined relationships between the military, intelligence, and private companies. Thank you @TheBushCenter for this important conversation. https://t.co/8qngsPwFrb

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: Central Virginians, the deadline to register to vote – either in person or online – has been extended to 11:59 pm, Thursday, October 15. Are you registered? Double check now! Visit https://t.co/jGHfBW3Ovw today. #VA07 https://t.co/jVr1xaFgmn

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: The proposed #SocialSecurity increase of 1.3% falls far behind the sharp rise of prescription drug costs (up 5.2% on average this year.) Many American seniors are financially hurting, and I'm joining @RepPeterDeFazio to push for a 3% increase in 2021. https://t.co/143uboBP0w

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: Cybercrimes ruin lives and take an enormous toll on our economy. As online threats multiply by the hour, I'm proud to join @RepJohnKatko on the bipartisan Cyber Essentials Act. This bill would help provide Americans with practical tools & guidance for protecting themselves. #VA07

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: A diet with the right amount of dairy is proven to help lower the risk of cardiovascular disease, bone fractures, & colorectal cancer. I recently wrote to ask HHS & USDA to update their guidelines to help support healthier families and a stronger market for American dairy farms. https://t.co/YZpdnUw0qA

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text:
Every day, the need for relief in #VA07 becomes more urgent. Restaurant owners need a bipartisan bill that can actually become law – that's why I cosponsored the RESTAURANTS Act, which would provide $120 billion in grants to revitalize the industry.
https://t.co/Xqm4H7CdIq

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: Today's news is deeply disturbing. It confirms what law enforcement and intelligence agencies have been warning for years – that domestic terrorism is a growing threat to our national security, and the safety of the American people.

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text:
I'm appalled to learn that the recently disrupted plot to kidnap Gov. Whitmer of Michigan also included plans to kidnap Gov. Northam here in our Commonwealth.

I'm deeply thankful for the local, state, & federal law enforcement officers who thwarted this domestic terror plot.

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: Working across the aisle pays off! Last month, I fought to include the extension of school meal programs in the bipartisan funding bill. On Friday, @USDA extended them through June 2021. We're one big step closer to making sure no #VA07 child goes hungry. https://t.co/hMooGkVz77

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: Happy birthday @RepMcEachin! Whether working together to secure vital investments in broadband, or fighting for the supplies & support that Central Virginia families need to stay safe during this pandemic, I’m honored to serve our region alongside such a dedicated public servant.

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: Stories like this are repeated all over #VA07 and the country. More than ever, students need reliable internet access. I've fought to cut burdensome penalties for rural internet providers and strengthen broadband funding in COVID-19 relief legislation. https://t.co/YIkEn1egLt

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: There are many factors driving the prescription drug affordability crisis, and lasting progress will require bipartisan cooperation. Our goal needs to be reducing the financial burden that seniors, veterans, and patients face EVERY month – not just in an election season. #VA07

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: I voted to pass the Lower Drug Costs Now Act in December. 9 months later, it's still stalled in the Senate. This bill would empower Medicare to negotiate with drug makers and fight for lower drug prices for American seniors. #VA07 https://t.co/KOWiW8UmvN

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: The Biologic Patent Transparency Act (introduced) would stop big drug companies from blocking cheaper, generic drugs from reaching the market. The CREATES Act (cosponsored) would give patients more choice and greater access to affordable generics. https://t.co/ijk1DMNJDM

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: I've worked on two bipartisan bills that would work to break the stranglehold that big pharmaceutical companies have on some of the medications #VA07 residents rely on the most – the CREATES Act and the Biologic Patent Transparency Act. More on those: https://t.co/43YTFaSf7i

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: My bipartisan Public Disclosure of Drug Discounts Act would shine light on the closed-door price deals that go on between pharmaceutical companies and PBMs. This bill passed the House unanimously, and is waiting for a vote in the Senate. #VA07 https://t.co/pXtbKeszkR

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text:
My office has gathered stories on prescription drug costs from more than 3,500 Virginians. Many pay more than $100/month, & some even pay thousands of dollars.
 
A one-time gimmick won't help reduce costs long term – but here are some measures that could: 
https://t.co/fbHWeadhlE

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text:
The day any lawmaker chooses whether or not to deliver relief to the American people based on the electoral benefits, and not the real needs of the people we serve, is the day that lawmaker should consider a different line of work. #VA07
https://t.co/EXJhy5iLE7

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: I'm glad to see CARES Act funds going to support a safe schoolyear for #VA07 kids. Many U.S. communities are still in need, and Congress should stay focused on meeting that need. Political grandstanding is a distraction the American people can't afford. https://t.co/GfGBEGbCR2

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text:
The global COVID-19 pandemic has underscored that infectious disease is a national security issue. In a recent hearing, @HouseForeign discussed how U.S. security agencies can become more resilient in case of future pandemics or other biological threats.
https://t.co/tdA9cwc283

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text:
#VA07 teachers and students are tackling steep challenges this school year, and this support is much-needed. I'm glad to see CARES Act funds going to our communities to help public schools deliver a safe, high-quality education for all Virginia kids.
https://t.co/n4b98uvRNp

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text:
If you are experiencing violence, sexual assault, or abuse at the hands of a family member or partner – 

It's not your fault. You're not alone. People are here to help you.

Call the 24/7 @VDSS hotline at (800) 838-8238 or text (804) 793-9999. 

#DomesticViolenceAwarenessMonth

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: Wetlands aren't just beautiful – they also provide vital economic benefits like protecting property from floods, generating recreation revenue, and more. I appreciated the chance to hear about how groups like @DucksUnlimited are continuing their important work during COVID-19. https://t.co/Sv5QbgvzlO

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: As the 2001 #AUMF continues to authorize U.S. military action in Afghanistan & dozens of other places around the globe, I'll continue working across the aisle to reform it. Congress must be held accountable for their votes to send Americans off to war. https://t.co/by6XqhNDtH

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: On the 19th anniversary of the start of the War in Afghanistan, I'm remembering the immense sacrifices made by our servicemembers, their families, and our allies overseas. The decision to send Americans into harm's way is a monumental one, with impacts that can last for decades.

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: Real livelihoods are on the line — including in Central Virginia, and we can’t stop fighting for the people we serve. Both Democrats and Republicans must recommit to good-faith negotiations. (5/5)

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: The American people are tired of the political maneuvering and partisanship that has plagued Capitol Hill throughout the latter portion of the pandemic. (4/5)

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text: I’ve been vocal about the need for a bipartisan path forward on direct payments, unemployment assistance, and additional support for businesses — and the President throwing in the towel is not an acceptable option. (3/5)

name: Rep. Abigail Spanberger
tweet_text:
Just today, we heard from the Chairman of the Federal Reserve about the pressing need for additional action from Congress, or else risk further economic disaster. (2/5)

https://t.co/Ds7Ql8Req2
